title: How to Remove an Ink Stain from a Dryer Drum

steps.title: Unplug the dryer to protect yourself from electrical shock.
steps.content: Unplug the dryer to protect yourself from electrical shock. You can get electrocuted if you clean a dryer with water while it is still plugged in. Unplug the dryer before you begin to stay safe. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Wipe out the inside of the dryer with a rag soaked in soapy water.
steps.content: Wipe out the inside of the dryer with a rag soaked in soapy water. Fill a small bowl or bucket with warm water and a few drops of dish soap. You can use any type of dish soap that you have on hand. Then, dip a clean dish rag into the soapy water and wring it out. Use the rag to wipe the inside of the dryer wherever it is stained. Apply medium to hard pressure to scrub the stains. [2] X Research source Check after a few seconds to see if the stain is coming up. If it is, keep scrubbing. If not, you might need to try a different option.

steps.title: Rinse the rag and wipe out the dryer again.
steps.content: Rinse the rag and wipe out the dryer again. After you finish scrubbing the stains in the dryer, hold the rag under warm, running water. Then, wring it out and wipe out the inside of the dryer again to remove the soap residue. [3] X Research source Your dryer is safe to use again after you finish wiping it out. Plug it back in after you finish cleaning it.

steps.title: Unplug the dryer if you’ll be cleaning out the inside by hand.
steps.content: Unplug the dryer if you’ll be cleaning out the inside by hand. Cleaning the inside of a dryer while it is still plugged in puts you at risk of electric shock. Unplug the dryer before you start cleaning it if you’ll be cleaning it out by hand. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Scrub the dryer with a Magic Eraser for a chemical-free option.
steps.content: Scrub the dryer with a Magic Eraser for a chemical-free option. A Magic Eraser is a special sponge made of melamine foam. Wet the Magic Eraser sponge with water and wring it out. Wipe the inside of the dryer with the sponge to remove the ink stains. Keep scrubbing until all of the stains are gone. [5] X Research source Rinse and wring out the sponge as needed. You may have to apply medium to hard pressure depending on how bad the stains are. For example, if the stains are from a permanent marker, you might need to scrub them harder than if they’re from a pen.

steps.title: Spray fabric stain remover on the ink spots if there's time to let the product sit.
steps.content: Spray fabric stain remover on the ink spots if there's time to let the product sit. Spray the product on the ink stains inside of your dryer. Let it sit for about 5 minutes. Then, wipe the dryer clean with a damp paper towel. [6] X Research source You can purchase stain pre-treatment sprays in the laundry department of a grocery store.

steps.title: Use Goo Gone to easily clean ink from the inside of the dryer.
steps.content: Use Goo Gone to easily clean ink from the inside of the dryer. This product is alcohol-free, so it’s safe to use on the inside of a dryer. Apply the product to a rag and then wipe the inside of the dryer with the damp rag. The ink should come off of the dryer drum easily. Then, use a wet rag with a few drops of dish soap to wipe away the remaining Goo Gone. Follow that by wiping out the dryer with a wet rag to remove the soap. [7] X Research source Do not use “Goof Off” as this product is flammable. Only use the product “Goo Gone” if you try this option.

steps.title: Dry a bleach-soaked towel to clean the dryer while it's running.
steps.content: Dry a bleach-soaked towel to clean the dryer while it's running. Fill a small bucket with 1 US gal (3.8 L) of water and 8 fl oz (240 mL) of bleach. Then, place a towel into the solution and allow it to get soaked. Put on a pair of rubber gloves and pull the towel out. Wring it out as much as possible and then put it in the dryer without any other items. Turn the dryer on high and run it until the towel is dry. [8] X Research source When you remove the towel from the dryer, the ink stains should be gone. However, make sure to run a couple of loads of whites through the dryer next to ensure that all of the bleach residue is gone. You may also want to wipe out the inside of the dryer with a damp rag to ensure that there is no bleach residue left. Make sure to unplug the dryer before you wipe it out. It's best to toss the towel after using it so the ink stains don't transfer to other items the next time you wash it.

steps.title: Treat stubborn ink stains with nail polish remover and a damp cloth.
steps.content: Treat stubborn ink stains with nail polish remover and a damp cloth. Moisten a cotton ball with nail polish remover and dab it on the ink stains in the dryer. Repeat until all of the ink stains are gone. Then, wipe out the inside of the dryer with a damp cloth to remove the nail polish residue. [9] X Research source Make sure to wipe the inside of the dryer thoroughly with the wet rag to get all of the nail polish remover residue off of it. Avoid inhaling the fumes if you use this option. Open a window and run a fan to help ventilate the room while you wipe out the dryer and don’t stick your head into the dryer.
